snippet: Because California has been without a state budget since July 1, the rating on about $2 billion of various California agency and public works board debt obligations secured by state appropriations is being reviewed for a possible downgrade by the ...
lead_paragraph: Because California has been without a state budget since July 1, the rating on about $2 billion of various California agency and public works board debt obligations secured by state appropriations is being reviewed for a possible downgrade by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The credit-rating concern conditioned the review on the state's appropriating about $110 million to make debt-service payments, due around Sept. 1. "Under the term of most of the underlying lease agreements, the state is obligated to budget and appropriate for the use of leased assets, which consist primarily of state prisons, state buildings and higher education facilities," S.& P. said.

headline.main: California Debt of $2 Billion Is Put Under S.& P. Review
